en.value: Do you have a table for four?
Having conversations in a restaurant and talking with the waiter - Some vs. any
Can we see the specials?
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
a reservation
Do you have a reservation?
booked
We're fully booked.
You want a table at a restaurant: what do you need?
a reservation
a restaurant
a reputation
True or false?
The restaurant has tables available.
The restaurant doesn't have any tables available.
option
Do you have any vegan options?
Here's a tip!
If you have specific dietary requirements you may ask for an option that can suit you. Below are some common ones:
Do you have any vegetarian options?
Do you have any gluten-free options?
Do you have any dairy-free options?
specials
Would you like to see the specials?
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Are there vegetarian [k]options[/k] in the [k]specials[/k]?
specifics
open
starter
Are you having a starter?
main
And for the main course?
dessert
Would you like a dessert?

Some restaurants may serve a "set menu". In these menus you either have a smaller choice of three or four dishes, or you don't choose the dishes at all, as the restaurant chef has already decided them for you!
starter tip booked dessert menu set [h]main[/h]
Select the largest course of a meal.
With which course does the meal usually end?
dessert
desert
destiny
starter
This course often comes first during a meal.
to tip
How much shall we tip?

In some countries you are expected to tip your waiters a certain percentage at the end of your meal. In other places a service charge may be added to your check. We can use the word "tip" as both a verb and a noun. See the examples below!
Did you tip the waiter?
Is this enough of a tip?
Shall we leave a tip?
I'm allergic to...
I'm allergic to peanuts.
How would we say that we can't eat something?
I'm allergic to...
I'm aggressive to...
I'm around to...
Select the word for the money you might give a waiter at the end of a meal.
allergic dessert [h]tip[/h] menu set meal course
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
A couple are eating at a restaurant.
I'm glad we [k]reserved[/k] a table, the place seems totally [k]booked[/k]!
The [k]specials[/k] look really nice!
They do, but I'm afraid they don't have a gluten-free [k]option[/k].
If you say you're [k]allergic[/k] to it, I'm sure they can sort it out!
That's true. Do you want to share the mozzarella as a [k]starter[/k]?
Yes! I'm having the chicken as a [k]main[/k].
And then we can share [k]dessert[/k] like always!
Holly
Tom
Listen carefully.
Holly is glad the restaurant is fully booked.
Holly is glad that they reserved a table.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
If you say you're [k]allergic[/k] to it, I'm sure they can sort it out!
alliance
Fill in the gap using the image.
[k]Dessert[/k] is my favourite part of any meal.
Listen to the audio and select the correct option.
Holly thinks the specials look nice, but is afraid there isn't a gluten-free option.
Holly doesn't like the specials because there are no options for her.
Tom wants Holly to like the specials even though there isn't a gluten-free option.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Would you like to hear tonight's [k]specials[/k]?
Listen carefully.
Tom is getting his own dessert.
Tom is getting his own main.
Do we need to [k]tip[/k] or is the service charge included?
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Do you want to share the mozzarella as a [k]starter[/k]?
The first course of a meal.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Do you have any vegetarian [k]o[/k][k]p[/k][k]t[/k][k]i[/k]ons?
Talk about a restaurant you've been to. What did you order? Did you have dessert? Did you tip the waiter?
I recently went to ... / I ordered ... / I tipped the waiter ... euros.
Grammar: Using "some" and "any" to talk about undefined quantities
"Some" and "any" are two very common and useful words. We use them to talk about quantities when it's not important or not easy to say exactly how much we refer to.
Could I get some bread, please?
Is there any bread left?
Are there any vegetarian options?
This question is about how many vegetarian options there are.
The word "any" refers to an undefined number.
We use "some" and "any" in similar situations, so it can be difficult to know when to use which. So first, let's take a look at "any", compare it to "some" and then practise both in context.
I'd like some water please.
In this sentence, "some water" can refer to one glass as well as two, or even more.
Would you like any starters?
This question asks for the number of starters.
The word "any"
We use "any" to suggest an undefined amount of something. We often use it in questions and negative sentences. Have a look at some examples!
I don't want any potatoes, thanks.
Do you have any food allergies?
You can pick any restaurant you like.
Select the words "any" refers to.
I don't have any [h]allergies[/h] at all.
Do you have any [h]free[/h] [h]tables[/h] tonight?

We usually use "any" with plural or uncountable nouns when we don't care about the exact amount or the specific type of something. What's more important is to find out if something's there at all. Have a look at an example.
Anna: Are there any free tables tonight?
Waiter: Sure! Would you like one near the window?
Anna: It doesn't matter, any is fine!
Listen to the audio.
Anna doesn't care where the table is, as long as there is one for her.
Do you have any [k]recommendations[/k]?
recommendation
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]Do[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]any[/k] [k]ideas[/k] [k]for[/k] [k]her birthday?[/k]
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I can't find any [k]plates[/k] in the kitchen.
plate
We can also use "any" to respond to questions. It helps us to say that we don't mind the specifics of something (e.g. which film we're going to watch).
Mark: Which film would you like to see?
Emma: Any!
Listen to the audio. How might we respond to say that we don't mind?
Any.
Some.
None.
Unfortunately we didn't get [k]any[/k] [k]tickets[/k] for the concert.
some
ticket
Complete the dialogue to say that you don't mind which table you sit at.

Waiter: "Would you like a table by the window?"  - 
You: "I don't mind, [k]any|any table[/k] is fine."
Quick summary of what we've learned about "any":

- We use "any" to ask if there is an undefined quantity of something.
- We use it when we want to say that we don't mind about the specifics.
- We mainly use "any" in negative sentences or questions where we are asking about the presence of something.
Do you have any gluten-free starters?
You can pick any table you like.
She didn't get any sleep last night.
I don't have any time to help.
The word "some"
We also use the word "some" to talk about an undefined quantity of something. In contrast to "any", we use it when we expect the presence of something.
There are some free tables outside.
Can I get some bread, please?
I'm buying some groceries.
There are some people waiting for a table at the bar.
This sentence only tells us that there are people waiting, but not exactly how many.
[k]Can[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]buy[/k] [k]some[/k] [k]cheese[/k] [k]for me?[/k]
Would you like some coffee?
This question is about how many cups of coffee someone wants.
"Some" refers to an indefinite amount of coffee.
There are [k]s[/k][k]o[/k][k]m[/k][k]e[/k] people waiting for a table at the bar.
Let's compare "any" and "some":
"Any" and "some" both refer to undefined quantities. We use them when the exact number of something isn't important. Let's recap the main differences.
Select what "any" and "some" have in common.
both refer to undefined quantities
both help us offer something
both refer to exact quantities
Generally, we use "any" in negative contexts (e.g. when we know / expect that something's not there). We say "some" in positive contexts (e.g. when we know / expect that something is there).
Situation: We've eaten a few slices of bread, and we think the bread might be finished. We ask: "Is there any bread left?"
Situation: We've just received the starters and want some bread. We ask: "Could I have some bread, please?"
Could I get [k]some[/k] napkins please?
any
Select the correct statement.
We use "any" to say that we don't have a certain thing.
We use "some" to say that we don't have a certain thing.
We use both to ask questions we expect a "yes" in response to.
Here's another example:
We would use "any" to say that we don't want something and we'd use "some" to say that we do want something.
I don't want any starters.
I would like some starters.
He wants [k]some[/k] coffee.
any
I don't want [k]a[/k][k]n[/k][k]y[/k] onions in my salad.
Here are some common phrases with "any" and "some" that we use a lot:
I didn't get any sleep last night.
Any luck?
I need some help.
We walk into a busy restaurant. It looks crowded. How might we ask for a table?
Are there any tables left?
Are there some tables left?
Are there tables here?
We finally sit down at our table. Complete the sentence to ask the waiter for water!
Could we get [k]some[/k] water?
any
All starters seem to include meat or fish. We can't find a single meat-free option. How can we ask if the restaurant offers vegetarian dishes?
Do you have any vegetarian options?
Do you want some vegetarian options?
How much are the vegetarian options?
We couldn't find [k]any[/k] vegan options.
some
We get our starters and would like bread with them. How could we ask the waiter for it?
Could we have [k]some[/k] bread, please?
You're keen on ordering dessert. Select the question that encourages a positive response.
Should we have some dessert?
Should we have any dessert?
Should you like dessert at all?
We decide to share a dessert. Someone asks: "Which one would you like?" Complete the response to say you don't mind which.
I don't mind, [k]any|any dessert[/k] is fine!
